File.Title: Inferior Olivary Nuclear Complex of the Rat: Morphology and Comments on the Principles of Organization Within the Olivocerebellar System
File.Authors: S. AUSIM AZIZI AM) D.J. WOODWARD

Abstract.S: This study was undertaken (1) to provide a description of the normal morphology and anatomical interrelationships within the inferior olivary cell groups and (2) to determine the topographical organization of projections from this nuclear complex to the cerebellum.

Conventional histological methods and the technique of retrograde transport of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and WGA-HRP in conjunction with the sensitive chromogen tetramethyl benzidine were used in this series of experiments.
In common with that of other animals, the inferior olivary nucleus of the rat consists of three subdivisions: the medial accessory olive (MAO), dorsal accessory olive (DAO), and principal olive (PO).
The MA0 is made of several subnuclei including a, b, c, and nucleus beta.
On the basis of their common connections, the smaller subnuclei, dorsal cap, ventrolateral outgrowth, and dorsomedial cell column can be considered as parts of the MAO.
The DAO is made of two subdivisions or lamellae-the dorsal and ventral folds-joined together laterally to form a twisted V-shaped structure.
The principal olive consists of dorsal and ventral lamellae.
A point-to-point projection was determined for four areas of the cerebellum: the anterior lobe, the posterior vermis, the intermediate and the lateral cerebellum.

Analysis of the details of the projection system revealed that distinct groups of cells, here referred to as lamellae, project to sagittal zones of the cerebellum. (1) The medial accessory olive appears to be composed of three lamellae: horizontal, vertical, and rostral.
The horizontal lamella (elsewhere denoted as groups a and b) projects to a sagittal zone in the vermal anterior lobe.

The vertical lamella (groups c, beta, dorsal cap, ventrolateral outgrowth, and dorsomedial cell column) projects to a sagittal zone in the posterior vermis and the flocculus, and the rostral lamella projects to the lateral cerebellum. (2) The dorsal accessory olive is composed of two distinct lamellae which we have previously denoted as the dorsal and ventral folds.

The dorsal fold projects to the vermal anterior lobe and receives afferents from the spinal cord, whereas the ventral fold projects to a sagittal zone in the intermediate cerebellum and receives afferents primarily from dorsal column nuclei. (3) The principal olive contains the two familiar lamellae: dorsal and ventral lamellae, each of which projects to a specific sagittal strip in the lateral cerebellum.
Each of these lamellae appears to process information from distinct ascending and descending systems.

Introduction.S: The determination of the nature of topographical organization of the large system of the olivocerebellar connections is of major importance in mammalian neuroanatomy.
Detailed studies of this system have been carried out in the cat (see Courville et al., '80; Brodal and Kawamura, '80).

Recent data on the topography and connections of the olivocerebellar system in the rat (Gwyn et al., '77; Furber and Watson, '83; Eisenman, '84; Payne et al., '85) have either studied small components of the system or have mainly confirmed the earlier studies on other mammals.
In this report we present new concepts on the organization within this system.
A more detailed analysis of point-to-point projections will be presented in later communications along with additional visual representations of the inferior olivary complex.
Structures in the brain have been traditionally grouped and classified on the basis of their histological disposition.

One way of grouping the olivary nuclei is to identify groups of olivary cells on the basis of their common afferents and efferents and to emphasize anatomical landmarks that perhaps are not detailed elsewhere.
In the present report, we have reviewed such an organization and have presented additional nomenclature on this basis.
As part of an analysis of this system, an initial task in our studies in the rat was to obtain a detailed understanding of the organization of the various components of the olivary nuclear complex.
A second phase of this work was to establish the nature of point-to-point connections from specific regions of the olive onto each major cerebellar lobule.
A third step was to relate our findings to the known topographically organized olivary afferents and to make some initial functional correlations.

To accomplish these ends, we examined a complete series of brainstem sections in considerable detail to establish the major regional boundaries of olivary zones as described in many vertebrate species including primates and humans (Kooy, '17) and more recently in the rat (Gwyn et al., '77), cat (Brodal, '40; Walberg, '56; Taber, '61), and monkey (Bowman and Sladek, '73).
Our study revealed a gross feature of the olivocerebellar projection in which the fiber system rotates 90" as it ascends to the cerebellar cortex.
Caudal olivary regions project to midline cerebellar areas, and rostral regions of the olive project to the hemispheres.
Analysis of the details of the projection system indicated that distinct groups of cells, here referred to as lamellae, project to sagittal zones of the cerebellar cortex.
Our study further revealed a complex organization of projections in the form of a banding pattern (perpendicular to lamellae) observed in multiple olivary areas of cells of origin.
A principle of organization appears to be that the lamellae form the basis of sagittal projection zones and bands form lobule projection modules.
Preliminary reports of portions of these data have appeared previously (McGrane et al., '77; Azizi et al., '78, '82).

Methods.S: A complete series of transverse sections, cut at 40 pm on a freezing microtome and stained with cresyl violet or neutral red, were examined throughout the extent of the olive of two albino and ten Long-Evans female hooded rats.

Seventy sections in each series were examined individually and the outlines of the olivary cell regions and ventral surface of the brainstem were drawn with the use of a drawing tube mounted on a Leitz Orthoplan microscope or an overhead projector.
A section-by-section analysis was essential to clarify transitions in olivary regions.
Portions of several rat brains (20 of 148) used in the entire series of experiments (as described below) were studied in equivalent detail to resolve transition areas.
A final summary series of outlines was prepared with slight adaptations to account for the most constant features among the many brainstems.
These were used to establish major boundaries between olivary subdivisions.
The method of retrograde transport of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) was employed systematically to explore the pattern of the olivary projections to the cerebellum.
One hundred forty-eight female hooded and albino rats weighing 180-280 g were used in this phase of the study.
Injections of 0.04-0.2 pl, 1040% solutions of HRP or WGA-HRP (2%) in water were made with glass micropipettes (35-75pm tips) attached to a 1-pl Hamilton syringe.
Placements of large injections were made into anterior, posterior, and lateral cerebellar lobules of 15 rats under pentobarbital anesthesia.

The remainder of the animals received small injections of HRP in lobules and sublobules of the anterior However, it could not be determined with certainty where the edge of the effective zone of axon terminal uptake was located.
Our opinion is that the effective injection zone is within the central region of the stained area.
Cells stained by retrograde transport of horseradish peroxidase were located on the transverse brainstem sections.
The low-power (10 X) objective was used to determine the location of the cells in a standard olivary series cut rostrocaudally.
The relative numbers of cells were manually translated into dot density diagrams to indicate the cell distribution within the olive.

Results.S: RESULTS
Gross organization

As in other mammalian species (Kooy, 17), most olivary neurons are located within the three major nuclei-the medial accessory olive (MAO), the dorsal accessory olive (DAO), and the principal olive (PO) (Gwyn et al., 77).
The minor nuclei from caudal to rostral are the dorsal cap (DC), the nucleus beta, the ventrolateral outgrowth (VLO), and the dorsomedial cell column (DMCC) (Fig. 1).
On the basis of their connections, these small subnuclei can be associated with the MAO; therefore, we will categorize them operationally as parts of the MAO.
An additional minor subnuclew is the dorsal fold (DF) of the DAO, which was first delineated by McGrane et al. ( 77).
An alternative way of organizing the cell groups within the inferior olivary complex entails the parcellation of the olivary nuclei into groups with common afferents and efferents.
Additional terms are necessary to appropriately explain some of the concepts and divisions.
The term, lamella, is applied here generically to denote groups of neurons with common afYerents and efferents.
These groups of cells mostly form plates or slabs and appear to be anatomically distinct subdivisions within the olive.
In the following description and in Table 1 and Figure 9, we have correlated this lamellar organization with the classically described olivary subnuclei.

Examination of serial coronal sections beginning at the caudal end of the I0 in the medulla showed that, moving rostrally, the caudal tip of the MA0 appears first as an oval-shaped group of cells lying about 0.3 mm caudal to the obex.
This small group is known as subgroup b (Fig. 1, sec. 1).
Slightly rostrally, this cell group enlarges dorsomedially and a smaller cell group, a, appears immediately lateral to it (Fig. 1, sec. 3).
Rostral to this, the first and second groups join, forming a continuous horizontal sheet of neurons.
This sheet of cells has unique afferents and efferents (see Discussion) and composes the lateral portion of the caudal half of the MAO.
We refer to this group of cells as the horizontal lamella.
Another cell group, c, appears adjacent to the midline and dorsomedial to the first cell group (Fig. 1, sec. 4).
The nucleus beta is located just ventral to the dorsal cap and is fused ventrally with subnucleus c (Fig. 1, secs. 7-11).
The nucleus beta in the rat is a group of cells distinct from c with a somewhat different pattern of projections to the cerebellum.
Caudally, subgroups c and beta are distinct (Fig. 1, secs 7,8); however, rostrally they form a continuous vertical slab of cells with common afTerents.
This vertical slab together with the smaller cell subgroups, dorsal cap, ventrolateral outgrowth, and dorsomedial cell column, form another lamella, the vertical lamella of the MAO.
This lamella, although not forming a continuous sheet, can be considered operationally as one unit (see Discussion).
Thus, the caudal and medial MA0 are made of two lamellae, oriented perpendicularly in an L shape.
At the level where the three parts of the MA0 (a, b, and c) join, the dorsal cap (DC) first appears (Fig. 1, sec. 5) and continues rostrally as the most dorsal and medial part of the MAO.
The ventrolateral outgrowth appears as a discrete cell group ventrolateral to the dorsal cap (Fig. 1, secs. 11, 121, joined with the nucleus beta.
The DMCC is located at a more rostral level.
The rostral portion of the main body of MA0 forms another slab of cells with distinct connections, the rostral lamella.
In the rat, this lamella of cells appears to form the rostral continuation of groups b and c; however, it has separate afferents and efferents from b and c (see Discussion).
The dorsal accessory olive first appears as a flat group of cells, dorsal to the MAO.
Slightly rostral, the DAO enlarges, extending ventrolaterally about 1.2 mm from the midline to the ventral surface of the brainstem (Fig. 1, secs. 9-11).
More rostral it separates into two layers or lamellae, joined laterally.
The most dorsal and caudal lamella is defined here as the dorsal fold and the ventral layer or lamella is referred to here as the ventral fold (Fig. 1, secs.
The dorsal and ventral folds together form the twisted, V-shaped structure of the DAO.
The term fold has been used here to describe the folding of the two lamellae of the DAO that form the V-shape.
It will be noted later that significant functional differences exist between the dorsal and ventral folds.
The principal olive originates as a small group of cells lateral to the MA0 and ventral to the dorsal fold.
This group of cells quickly forms the dorsal lamella of the principal olive.
The ventral lamella of the principal olive extends dorsomedially from the dorsal lamella (Fig. 1, secs. 14, 15).
The transition zone refers to the area of the inferior olivary complex where relatively rapid changes in crosssectional appearance of the inferior olive take place (Fig. 1, secs. 10-15).

Rostra1 to the transition zone, the olive consists primarily of a three-layered sigmoid structure with the ventral fold of DAO joined medially to the dorsal lamella of the PO, which in turn is joined laterally to the ventral lamella of the PO.
The rostral lamella of the MA0 lies ventral to the sigmoid structure and the DMCC occupies a midline site.
The olive exhibits this basic confguration from the end of the transition zone to its rostral end.
The minor subnuclei, the dorsal cap, and the nucleus beta are located caudally to the transition zone.
The ventrolatera1 outgrowth and the dorsal fold of DAO occur just at the level of the transition zone, and the dorsomedial cell column is located rostrally to this area.
Topography of projections from the olivary complex

The series of injections in these experiments was designed to obtain information from major regions of the entire cerebellum: the anterior lobe, the posterior vermis, the intermediate zone, and the lateral hemisphere.
Multiple injection sites were required to cover each major lobule, and the resulting label appeared in neurons within distinctly different olivary nuclei, permitting a lobule-by-lobule comparison.
The olivary labeling shown on the following series of coronal olivary maps represents a compilation of data obtained from many individual HRP injections.
Figure 2 demonstrates two injection sites and labeling in the olive (Fig.2C,D) following HRP injections in lobule VIb-c (Fig. 2 4 .
projectiom to the anterior lobe of the cerebellum.
Twenty-five animals were used in this phase of the study.
The results revealed that the anterior lobe receives projections from the horizontal lamella (groups a and b) in the caudal MA0 and almost the entire DAO.

TTE.S: The series includedHRP injections into vermal lobules 111, IV, and V.
Midline vermal injections in these lobules labeled cells in the caudolateral MA0 (Fig. 3C, secs. 1-11).
The clusters of cells labeled with these injections were located in subnuclei a and b, an area more lateral than those labeled with injections in posterior vermis (see below).
On the other hand, placements of HRP laterally in lobules IV and V tended to label the DAO heavily (Fig. 3C, secs. 9-18, solid squares).
Labeled cells were observed in both the dorsal fold and lateral aspects of the ventral fold of the DAO, as well as in the lateral aspect of rostral MA0 (Fig. 3C, secs. 1117).
Results from three cases,A-96, A-42, and CH-19, with injections in lobules N and V are represented in Figure 4C secs. 9-18 (solid squares).

Results.S: Projections to the posterior vermis and the tlocculus.
The results (Fig. 4f showed that the posterior vermis receives projections primarily from the vertical lamella (groups c and beta) in the caudal MAO.

TTE.S: Fifty-two posterior vermal injections in lobules VIa-c, VII, VIII, and IXa-c were analyzed.

Placement of HRP in lobule VIa of seven rats resulted in scattered labeling in groups b and c (Fig. 4C, secs. 1-10, open triangles), whereas injections in lobule VIb-c labeled neurons in subnuclei c and beta.

Results.S: Results from three cases, A-43, A-53, and CH-14, are presented in Figure 4C secs. 6-11 (solid triangles).

TTE.S: Eight successful injections covering the entire lobule VII were analyzed.
Results from three cases are presented in Figure 4C (open circles).
Labeled cells were observed in subnucleus c and nucleus beta at the level of the transition zone.
Injections of HRP into lobule VIII were attempted in ten animals.
Nine of these cases were successful in the sense that the injection site was within the vermal lobule VIII.
These injections labeled olivary neurons in the caudal MA0 (subnucleus b), the medial MA0 (subnucleus c), and nucleus beta (Fig. 4, solid circles).

Results.S: Cases A-97, A-75, and A-128 are depicted in Figure 4C, secs. 1-9 (solid circles).

TTE.S: Eighteen cases with successful injections in sublobules IXa-c were examined.
Each of these injections covered part or all of one or more of the sublobules IXa-c.
HRP-labeled cells were observed in olivary areas at the transition zone level in the beta nucleus, subnucleus c, and the dorsal cap (Fig. 4, secs. 5-13, open squares).

It appears that the midline vermal lobule IXa-c receives afferents mainly from the nucleus beta, while the lateral area of the uvula is the site of termination of climbing fibers from the subnucleus c (Fig. 4).
A few cells were observed in the dorsal cap of Kooy.
Injections of HRP in the flocculus, without involvement of the paraflocculus, labeled olivary neurons only in the dorsal cap of Kooy (Fig. 4C, secs. 5-12, solid squares).

Results.S: The flocculus has been considered together with the midvermal region because flocculus and parts of posterior midvermis (uvula) receive inputs from common olivary regions, i.e., the vertical lamella or specifically the dorsal cap.
The vertical lamella appears to be a functionally distinct zone of the olive, receiving mainly visual and vestibular afferents and relaying this information to the flocculus and midvermis.
Our results demonstrate that, for the most part, the neurons that project to the posterior vermis are located within the vertical lamella of the MA0 (Fig. 4, secs. 1-12).

It should be noted that the extensive series of small HRP injections in lobules VIbc-IX of different animals allows an overview of the olivary projections to a complete sagittal cerebellar zone as previously defined and discussed (Armstrong et al., '74; Courville, '75; Groenewegen and Voogd, 77; Chan-Palay et al., '77; Groenewegen et al., '79).

Thus, these results reveal that the sagittal zonation in the cerebellum corresponds to a topographical organization within the inferior olive such that each sagittal strip of climbing fibers may originate from a distinct lamella of neurons in the inferior olive.
Projections to the posterior lobe intermediate zone.

TTE.S: Twenty-six cases with injections in the intermediate region of the posterior lobe were analyzed.
In the rat we presumed the area slightly medial as well as lateral to the longitudinal vessels demarcating the vermis and lateral hemisphere to be the intermediate area.
Most of the labeling found following injections in this area was concentrated in the caudal half of rostral lamella of MA0 and the medial portion of the ventral fold of the DAO.
Six HRP injections in the intermediate lobule VI labeled the ventral caudal half of the rostral lamella of MA0 (Fig. 5C, secs. 14-21, solid triangles).
Some labeled cells were found in dorsomedial regions of the DAO at the junction of this subnucleus and the PO.
Injections in the intermediate lobule VII labeled cells in medial MA0 and the medial area of the ventral fold of DAO at the level of the transition zone (Fig. 5, secs. 14-20, solid circles).

In six different cases with injections in intermediate areas of crura I and 11, the number of labeled cells observed in the inferior olive was comparatively small, although a large number of cells were filled with HRP in the pons and in the lateral reticular nucleus.

Placements of HRP in the medial area of the paramedian lobule resulted in labeling of distinct areas within the rostral lamella of MA0 and the medial region of the ventral fold of DAO (Fig. 5, secs. 14-18, open triangles).
The nucleotopic projection is similar to that observed for the intermediate zones of lobulus simplex and for crura I and 11.
HRP placements in intermediate areas of lobule VIII, in five different animals, resulted in labeling in the lateral part of the ventral fold of the DAO (Fig. 5C, secs. 14-19, open squares).

Results.S: There is a nucleotopic organization within the caudal portion of the rostral lamella of MA0 with regard to projections to the intermediate zones of simplex, crura I and 11, and the paramedian lobule (Fig. 5, secs. 16-19).
Neurons that project to simplex (solid triangles) are located ventrally.

Those projecting to crura I and I1 (solid circles) are located dorsally, while the group of cells that contributes climbing fibers to the paramedian lobule (open triangles) is located between these two tiers (Fig. 5, secs. 16-19).

Overall,the intermediate zones of the cerebellum receive climbing fiber projections from the caudal aspect of the rostral lamella of the MA0 and the medial aspect of the ventral fold of the DAO at the level of the transition zone.
Projections to the cerebellar hemispheres.
The lateral cerebellum was found to receive projections mainly from rostral olive.
Virtually all of the labeled cells were located in the rostral aspect of the rostral lamella of MA0 and both lamellae of PO.
In 33 animals, HRP was injected laterally in lobulus simplex, crus I and crus 11, the paramedian lobule, the lateral pyramis, and the paraflocculus.
These injection sites tended to be larger than those in vermal areas and resulted in correspondingly heavier labeling.

TTE.S: In five animals with injections in lobulus simplex, a zone of heavy labeling was present in the dorsomedial zone of the rostral lamella of MA0 that extended from near its rostral tip to the transition zone.
A few labeled cells were also noted in the DMCC.
Also, a group of cells in the medial DAO was heavily labeled (Fig. 6C, secs. 13-20, solid circles).
Three injections in crus I labeled cells in the midsection of the ventral lamella of the PO (Fig. 6C, secs. 15-19, solid squares).
Eight HRP injections in crus I1 labeled olivary neurons that were diffusely scattered at the extreme rostral end of the MA0 and the ventral lamella of the PO(Fig. 6C, secs. 14-22, solid triangles).
The distribution of labeled cells found afterinjections in the paramedian lobule was slightly different than that present after injections of crura I and 11.
Labeled olivary cells were found in the midsection of both ventral and dorsal lamellae of the PO (Fig. 6C, secs. 15-21, open circles).
Three cases (A-54, CH-19, and CH-13) demonstrated this pattern of labeling.
Two cases with injections in the lateral region of lobule VIII demonstrated labeled cells in the far caudal aspects of the PO (Fig. 6C, secs. 11, 12, open squares).
Twelve cases with successful injections in the pardocculus were analyzed.
Two major groups of olivary neurons were labeled.
A column of labeled cells, about 800 pm long, was located in the ventral zone of the rostral MAO.

A second group of cells, located in the junction between dorsal and ventral lamellae of the PO, was labeled throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the principal olive (Fig. 6, secs. 1322, open triangles).

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

In the course of this study, we addressed the issue of the conformation and topographical organization of the inferior olive in the rat as well as the patterns of organization within its olivocerebellar system.
A comprehensive analy sis of the totality of efferents from the inferior olivary complex to the cerebellum proved critical for identifying the lamellar organization within this system.
Conversely, the functional significance of the lamellae became clear through a process of examination of afferents to each lamella.

In addition, as is noted in the following discussion, the inferior olive can be divided on the basis of common connections into three functional regions that include one or more lamellae within the traditional olivary subcomponents of the MAO, DAO, and PO.
The functional zones include a somatosensory zone in the caudal olive, a visualvestibular zone, and an integrative zone.
The following discussion of the connections of traditional olivary subnuclei reviews the basis for emerging concepts of lamellar and functional organization of the olivary complex.
The medial accessory olive (MAO)
Morphology.

This subnucleus in the rat is similar to the homologous regions in the cat and monkey (Brodal, '40; Taber, '61; Bowman and Sladek, '73) and constitutes the largest subgroup of the inferior olivary complex.
In marsupials the MA0 is laterally displaced (Martin et al., '75; Watson and Herron, '77) due to a slightly different course of ontogeny in these mammals.
On the basis of their common connections we have divided the MA0 into three lamellae (see Results and belowbthe rostral lamella, the vertical lamella, and the caudally located horizontal lamella.
Merents and efferents.
We propose that the MA0 can be divided into three functional subdivisions which parallel the lamellar organization.
This conclusion is based both on the results of this study and on a review of the literature in the rat and other species (see below).
These three regions or lamellae are partially coextensive and are the following: The horizontal lamella.
This region includes the caudallateral portion of the MA0 (subgroups a and b) and is primarily a somatosensory zone (see Figs. 3, 9).
Results of this study show that this area of MA0 contributes climbing fibers primarily to the midline vermal area of the anterior lobe of the cerebellum in the rat (Fig. 3).
These results are similar to those in the cat (Brodal and Walberg, '77) and opossum (Martin et al., '80, '82).
The caudal-latera1 portion of the MA0 has similar afferents to the DAO.

It has been shown in the rat (Swenson and Castro, '83a,b), cat (Mizuno, '66; Boesten and Voogd, '75; Berkley and Worden, '78; Berkley and Hand, '78; Walberg, '82; Molinari, '84), and monkey (Kalil, '79) that the dorsal column nuclei, spinal cord, and the spinal trigeminal nucleus project to the caudal MA0 (subgroups a and b).

It appears that the caudal-lateral MAO, or horizontal lamella, in conjunction with the DAO, receives peripheral somatosensory inputs mainly from the spinal cord and the dorsal column nuclei and projects to the midvermal area of the anterior cerebellum.
The vertical lamella.
Based on afferents and efferents this aggregate appears to be involved with visual and vestibular functions.

The results of the present study demonstrate that the cell groups that compose the vertical lamella, i.e., subgroups c, beta, the dorsal cap (of Kooy), the ventrolateral outgrowth, and the dorsomedial cell column all project to a midline strip of vermal lobules VIVIII and to a slightly lateral zone of vermal lobule IX (Figs. 4, 7).
This projection pattern is in agreement with those in the cat (Hoddevik et al., '76; Brodal, '761, monkey (Brodal and Brodal, '81, '82), and opossum (Linauts and Martin, '78b).
The results of our previous studies in the rat (Azizi et al., '82) have demonstrated that parts of the vertical lamella (subnucleus c) receives afferents from the superior colliculus.
Other authors (Graham, '77; Weber et al., '78; SaintCyr and Courville, '82, in the cat; Frankfurter et al., '76, in primates) have shown a similar tecto-olivary projection.
The nucleus beta receives additional afferents from the pretectal (Walberg et al., '81; Martin et al., '82), fastigial (Sugimoto et al., '80), and vestibular nuclei (Saint-Cyr and Courville, '79).
Such a tecto-olivomidvermal projection has been shown electrophysiologically in the cat (Jeneskog, '83).
The dorsomedial cell column receives afferents from the vestibular nuclei and the interstitial nucleus of Cajal (Saint-Cyr and Courville, '79) and projects to the uvula (Brodal, '76; this study).
The ventrolateral outgrowth receives fibers from the pretectal areas (Walberg et al., '81) and projects to the uvula as well.
These cerebellar targets can be seen as portions of an overall sagittal projection zone of the medial MA0 (Fig. 7).

A well-studied subnucleus, the dorsal cap of Kooy, is known to have a relatively complex input and output pattern (Mizuno et al., '73; Maekawa and Simpson, '73; Frankfurter et al., '76; Weber and Harting, '80; Walberg et al., '81).
The results of the present investigation reveal that the dorsal cap projects to the flocculus and uvula, corroborating the results of a previous study in the rat (Blanks et al., '83) (Fig. 4).

The caudal aspect of this subnucleus receives fibers from the nucleus of the optic tract and the dorsal terminal nucleus of the accessory optic tract that mediate visual information to the flocculus from the ipsilateral eye (Maekawa and Takeda, '79; Takeda and Maekawa, '80).

The rostral aspect of this subnucleus is the site of termination of axons from the ventromedial tegmental area and mediates visual information to the dorsomedial flocculus from the contralateral eye (Alley et al., '75; Maekawa and Takeda, '79; Takeda and Maekawa, '80), indicatthe dorsal cap integrates information from both
ing that eyes.
Thus, it appears that the medial MA0 is mostly, if not completely, involved with visual and vestibular functions (Fig. 9).
The rostral lamella This area encompasses the region of the main body of the MA0 rostral to the transition zone, referred to here as the rostral lamella.
Previous studies in the squirrel monkey (Rutherford and Gwyn, '80) have indicated that the rostral aspect of MA0 is composed of the anterior end of cell group a.
However, from our analysis it appears that in the rat this group of cells is the rostral end of groups b and c.
In future publications on the threedimensional structure of the inferior olive, the disposition as well as relations of this lamella with other cell groups will become more clear.

As will become apparent from the following discussion, the afferents and efferents of this group of cells are distinctly different from horizontal and vertical lamellae; therefore, this group is classified separately as a new lamella.

In the current study in the rat, the rostral aspect of this lamella was found to project to the contralateral paraflocculus and hemisphere including lobulus simplex, crura I and 11, and the paramedian lobule (Figs. 5, 6, 9).
The caudal area of this lamella projects to intermediate lobules VI, VII, and VIII.
The rostral lamella of MA0 appears to receive a variety of projections from motor areas in the midbrain.

By utilizing retrograde and anterograde methods, a descending projection system from the mesencephalon to the rostral MA0 was demonstrated in the cat (Takeda and Maekawa,'76; Saint-Cyr and Courville, '81, '821, opossum (Henkel et al., '73, and rat (Brown et al., '77; Swenson and Castro, '83a,b).

Further studies have suggested that the nucleus of Darkschewitsch (cat, Mabuchi and Kusama, '70; Onodera, '84; opossum, Linauts and Martin, '78a) and the periaqueductal gray (cat, Walberg, '74; rat, Swenson and Castro, '83b) send fibers to the rostral subdivision of the MAO.
It appears that this rostral subdivision of the MA0 receives projections from mesencephalic motor regions and projects to the lateral and vestibular cerebellum (Fig. 9).
Since the afferents and efferents of this nucleus are similar to those of the principal olive, this subdivision of the MA0 may function as a unit with the principal olive.
Dorsal accessory olive
Morphology.
This subnucleus is a V-shaped structure consisting of two lamellae: a small dorsocaudal lamella, named here the dorsal fold, and a more rostral and ventral lamella, the ventral fold.
The ventral fold is the larger of the two components (about two-thirds of the total volume of DAO) and most likely makes up a major fraction of the DAO in other species.

Our observations indicate that the DAO is an anatomically continuous structure and that the dorsal and ventral folds are fused in the lateral aspect of the subnucleus to construct the V-shape (Fig. 1).
This Vshape feature was first noted by Kooy ('17), who described its presence in the mammals other than the rat.
Efferents and afferents.
Analysis of the connections of this subnucleus indicates that the DAO is primarily related to the somatosensory system.
Results of the present study indicate that the DAO mainly projects to the anterior lobe and to the intermediate areas of the posterior lobe of the cerebellum (Figs. 3, 5).

Further analysis of our results disclosed that the dorsal fold (lamella) and the lateral regions of the ventral fold (lamella) project to the vermal anterior lobe (vermal zones b and c in the cat), whereas the more rostral and medial DAO (the entire ventral fold) projects to the intermediate zones of the anterior and posterior lobes (Figs. 3,5).
The clearly delineated sagittal cerebellar projection zones reinforce the gross anatomical designation of the two DAO regions.
These results are similar to those in the cat (Brodal and Walberg, '77; Kotchabhakdi et al., '78) for zones that can be equated to the dorsal and ventral folds of the rat.
Anatomical studies in monkey (Brodal and Brodal, '81, '82) and opossum (Linauts and Martin, '78b), although not as detailed as those in the cat, demonstrate the same general pattern of projections.

Electrophysiological studies (Gellman et al., '83, '85) of somatosensory areas of the inferior olive have shown that the dorsal fold in the cat contains a nearly complete, although diffuse, somatosensory map of the body, whereas the ventral fold has a more precise somatosensory map.
Our view is that the areas mapped by Gellman et al. ('83, '85) correspond to our dorsal and ventral folds in the rat and to the regions noted by Kooy ('17).

The map of Gellman et al. ('83) also corresponds well with the anatomical data describing afTerents to the DAO in the rat (Swenson and Castro, '83a), cat (Boeston and Voogd, '75; Berkley and Hand, '78; Berkley and Worden, '78), and opossum (Martin et al., '80, '82).

The anatomical studies have shown that the gracile nucleus projects to the lateral DAO and the cuneate nucleus to the medial DAO, while axons of the spinal trigeminal nucleus end in the most medial zone of the DAO (Walberg, '82).

Fibers from the spinal cord terminate in the lateralmost area of the DAO and cover the entire region corresponding to the dorsal fold (rat, Swenson and Castro, '83a; cat, Mizuno, '66; Boesten and Voogd, '75).

Electrophysiological studies have further described an extensive spino-olivocerebellar system that terminates in precise sagittal zones of the anterior lobe (Larson et al., '69a,b; Oscarsson and Sjolund, '77a-c; Sjolund, '78; Anderson and Nyquist, '83).

Thus it appears that the DAO receives a topographically organized somatosensory projection mainly from the periphery and that the dorsal fold, in effect, is dominated by afferents from the spinal cord.
The principal olivary nucleus
Morphology.
In rat the principal olive (PO) is small compared to the MA0 or DAO (Fig. 1).
Thus, the name designation is a misnomer in this animal because it is in fact a smaller subnucleus.

The PO in the rat is similar to those in the cat (Brodal, '40; Walberg, '56; Taber, '61) and monkey (Bowman and Sladek. '73). consisting of two lamellae, dorsal and ventral, which form a U-shaped configuration with the hilus opening medially.
However, the dorsal lamella can be observed in places to fuse with the ventral fold of the DAO.
In the opossum the PO has a slightly different shape, which may be due to a different course of ontogeny in the marsupials (Martin et al., '75; Watson and Herron, '77).
In primates, man, and elephants, this subnucleus is the largest component of the inferior olive, which exhibits many folds and lamellae (Kooy, '17; Jenkins, '05).

From the pattern of connectivity and its parallel increase in size with the lateral cerebellum, it appears that the evolution of this nucleus in mammals is commensurate with that of the lateral cerebellum (Kooy, '17; Larsell, '52).
Overall, it appears that the PO in the rat has an appropriate size relative to the development of the lateral cerebellum.
Efferents and afferents.
The results of this communication reveal that the PO mainly projects to the lateral cerebellum (Fig. 6).

These results are congruent with familar results in the cat (Brodal, '40; Brodal and Walberg, '77; Kotchabhakdi et al, '78) and monkey (Brodal and Brodal, '81, '82) and in somewhat general agreement with those in the opossum (Linauts and Martin, '78b).
The available data on the projections to the PO indicate that the perirubral area, the cortex, and the lateral cerebellar nuclei project to this nucleus.

The dorsal lamella of the PO receives projections from the parvicellular area of the red nucleus in the cat (Edwards, '72; Saint-Cyr and Courville, '82), monkey (Miller and Strominger, '73; Strominger et al., '791, and opossum (Linauts and Martin, '78a).
In the monkey, the rostral red nucleus may project to both lamellae (Strominger et al., '79).
In the rat, a projection from the red nucleus to the PO has also been shown (Swenson and Castro, '83a).
Another group of mesencephalic projections to the PO originates within the pretectal area and the central gray.

The pretectal area in the cat, specifically, the nucleus of the optic tract, projects to the dorsal lamella (Walberg et al., '81) while the periaquaductal gray (nucleus of Darkschewitsch) projects to ventral lamella of the PO (Walberg, '74; Saint-Cyr and Courville, '82).

Unlike the basilar pons that receives major projections from widespread areas of the cortex, the inferior olive is known only to receive projections from the motor cortex in the rat (Bishop et al., '76; Brown et al., '77; Swenson and Castro, '83a,b) and cat (Sousa-Pinto, '69; Sousa-Pinto and Brodal, '69; Berkley and Worden, '78).
However, other areas of the cerebral cortex may indirectly influence the PO via rubro-olivary fibers or other nuclei of the mesencephalon (Oka et al., '79).

A substantial unresolved issue is the identification of diverse areas of mesencephalon that project to the PO and, in turn, the resolution of the multiple afYerents that project to these mesencephalic areas.
Principles of organization within the olivocerebellar system
First, a global organization details the totality of projections.
A gross generalization is that the olivocerebellar fibers rotate 90" before reaching the cerebellar cortex.

The hemispheres of the cerebellum receive projections from rostral cells in the olive, while the anterior midvermis and Dosterior midvermis receive fibers from lateral and medial caudal olivary zones, respectively Fig. 8).
Second, the results have led us to propose that the olivary complex (the MAO, DAO, and PO) can be subdivided further into slablike lamellae, as have been described above.
At this point we can delineate a total of seven different lamellae based largely on the detailed information on the projections from olive to the cerebellar cortex (Fig. 9).
Two are the familiar dorsal and ventral lamellae of the PO.
The dorsal and ventral folds of the DAO constitute two additional lamellae.
Finally, the MA0 is divided into three lamellae-the rostral, the horizontal, and the vertical-with the latter including the dorsal cell outcroppings.
Most of the lamellae appear to be folds of slablike groupings of olivary projection neurons.
The dorsal and ventral lamellae of the PO and the two parts of the DAO clearly can be considered folds but the three parts of the MA0 are more accurately regarded as fused subunits pig. 9).
The principal distinguishing property of each lamella is that each unit projects to one of seven corresponding sagittal zones in the cerebellar cortex.
As shown in Figure 9, the two lamellae of the PO project to two zones in the cerebellar hemisphere.
The lamellae (folds) of the DAO correspond to two sagittal zones in the anterior lobe and intermediate zone.
The three lamellae of the MA0 correspond to three sagittal zones in the anterior and posterior vermal areas.
Thus, the seven lamellae correspond to seven sagittal zones in the cerebellar cortex.
A nomenclature has not appeared with regard to these zones in the rat.

We suggested that these are homologous to the following zones in the cat (Groenwegen et al., '79): (1) Zone 1 in the rat (Fig. 9) corresponds to zone B in the cat (Groenwegen et al., '79). (2) Zone 2 in the rat (Fig. 9) is homologous to zones C1 and C3 in the cat. (3) Zone 3 in the rat (Fig. 9) is homologous to the anterior part of zone A in the cat. (4) Zone 4 is homologous to the posterior part of zone A. (5) Zone 5 is homologous to C2. (6) Zones 6 and 7 are homologous to D.

The physical edges of each lamella project to an edge of each sagittal zone, at which point there occurs a transition in the zone of the olive that projects to the adjacent strip of cerebellar cortex.
Within a lamella, there is a continuous field of cells projecting onto a continuous surface of cerebellar cortex.
The borders of portions of the lamellae appear to be fused in a continuous cell mass both with the MA0 and the lateral bend of the PO.
However, a careful examination of the organization of the projections of neurons shows a discontinuity in cerebellar cortical targets at the points of fusion between the lamellae.
A third principle of organization is that the olivary complex can be divided into three functional zones on the basis of common connections (Fig. 9).
These functional zones may be composed of more than one lamellae.

They consist of the following: (1) The caudal somatic sensory zone primarily receives from the ascending somatic sensory pathways and includes both lamellae of the DAO (dorsal and ventral folds) and the horizontal lamella of the MA0 (Fig. 9, dotted area).
(2) The medial visual and vestibular zone includes the vertical lamella that consists of c and beta in the main body of MA0 along with the minor subnuclei.
This region re-
ceives from the mesencephalic visual-vestibular projects to posterior vermis and the flocculus.
(3) The rostral zone receives inputs mainly from telencephalic and diencephalic centers and includes both lamellae of PO and the rostral lamella of MA0 (Fig. 9).
A fourth principle of organization is revealed by the discovery of a system of bands of cells within the inferior olive rostral to the transition zone.
Each band includes the totality of projections to a single cerebellar hemispheric lobule.

If a small injection of HRP were to be made entirely confined within the cerebellar cortical region of a single sagittal zone, then a small cluster of olivary neurons would be retrogradely stained, located entirely within the lamella projecting to that sagittal zone.
If, on the other hand, the injection was to straddle two sagittal zones, the two resulting labeled clusters would be located in two olivary lamellae.
Invariably, such clusters are found in adjacent lamellae in the mediolateral direction (Fig. 10).

Finally, a series of overlapping injections covering the lateral portion of an entire single lobule (including the intermediate and lateral, but not the vermal portions) labels a series of olivary cell clusters within several lamellae, which correspond to the sagittal zones within that lobule.
Such olivary cell clusters define a band that traverses the olivary complex and that is oriented perpendicular to the lamellae.
Figure 11 illustrates the organization of a band corresponding to cells projecting to the paramedian lobule.
Bands extending mediolaterally have been identified for several of the cerebellar lobules (Fig. 10).

These bands are topographically organized within the olive as follows: (1) For lobulus simplex, a band of cells encompasses dorsomedial cell clusters in the MA0 and both lamellae of the PO and medial aspects of the DAO (Fig. 10, vertical lines).
(2) Lateral and ventral to the band projecting to the lobulus simplex is another band of cells that projects to the paramedian lobule.
This band traverses to MAO, DAO, and both lamellae of the PO (Fig. 10, gray areas).
(3) A band of cells occupying more ventral regions in the PO projects to crura I and I1 (Fig. 10, horizontal lines).
(4) A lateral band that occupies the ventral MA0 and lateral bend of the PO projects to the paraflocculus (Fig. 10, slanted lines).
Overall, the bands are stacked so that the projections to lobulus simplex are dorsal, to paraflocculus are ventral, and to crus I and I1 and paramedian are in between.
Such a banding pattern does not apply to the relatively narrow vermal region that receives afYerents from olivary regions caudal to the transition zone.
Relationship between the lamellar organization and cell bands
The current studv reveals Datterns of connectivity not emphasized previously.

Analys'is of results of multiple small HRP injections in single lobules of the cerebellum indicated that small clusters or patches of labeled cells within the olive form the basic units of the bands as well as the lamellae (Fig. 11).
For example, a patch projecting to the of the paramedian lobule is located in the most medial DAO.
This same cluster is also part of the ventral fold (lamella) Of the DAO.

The Patch Projecting to a slightly lateral area in the paramedian is located in the rostral MAO and a unit of another lamella, the rostra1 lamella Of the MA'' the Of to the lateral paramedian is located in the and forms portions of the dorsal and ventral lamella (Fig. 11).
The main point is that each cluster or patch within a cell band gives rise to a portion of the fibers in an individual sagittal zone.
A complete sagittal Strip is made Up Of C h S - ters or patches of cells from several cell bands.
These clusters are located physically adjacent to one another in a single olivary subnucleus pig. 11).
F~~ a group of subclusters all located in the rostral MA0 (the rostral lamella) combine to give rise to a sagittal strip on the media1 aspect of the hemisphere.

It should be noted that extremely nWOW Sagittal Strips may be visualized by any study of connectivity in which subportions of the lamellar structures are filled with anterogradely transported staining material.
A more detailed clarification of this postulated Organization Will be presented in later publications.
